definitions.definition: an area of water that has been created for people to swim in

examples.text: an indoor/outdoor pool
Does the hotel have a pool?
relaxing by the pool
He swam three lengths of the pool.
I left the diving pool after my session on the springboards.
A girl invited me over to her pool party.
I slipped on the wet pool deck and fell down.
Jack works there as a pool boy.
a 25 m lap pool
a unique new wave pool

phrases: the bottom, edge, middle, side, etc. of the pool

definitions.definition: the building that contains a public pool
a small area of still water, especially one that has formed naturally

examples.text: freshwater/thermal pools
Rhinos are fond of wallowing in muddy pools and sandy riverbeds.
The waterfall cascades into the pool below.
There was a pool of water at the bottom of the garden.
The park is full of hot water springs and bubbling mud pools.
a shallow pool full of red carp

definitions.definition: a small amount of liquid or light lying on a surface

examples.text: The body was lying in a pool of blood.
a pool of light
The water ran down out of their clothes and formed a pool on floor.
The wick floated in a pool of oil.
pools of water

definitions.definition: a supply of things or money that is shared by a group of people and can be used when needed

examples.text: a pool of cars used by the firm’s sales force
a pool car
They draw on funds from a common pool.
They will share a limited pool of money with other defendants.
a shrinking pool of assets
The purpose of an insurance company is to provide a pool of funds from which to meet claims made by its customers.
a growing pool of data
a vast pool of knowledge on best practices

definitions.definition: a group of people available for work when needed

examples.text: a pool of cheap labour
I started my career in the **typing pool** *(= a group of people who shared a company’s typing work)* over 40 years ago.
A member of the press pool shouted out a question to the president.
There's a great talent pool in the business community.
We need to increase our applicant pool.
a method of expanding the pool of potential investors
a strong pool of talent in the company
the available pool of really good people

definitions.definition: a game for two people played with 16 balls on a table, often in pubs and bars. Players use cues (= long sticks) to try to hit the balls into pockets at the edge of the table.

examples.text: a pool table
to shoot *(= play)* pool
Do you play pool?

definitions.definition: a form of gambling in the UK in which people try to win money by saying what the results of football matches will be

examples.text: He does the pools every week.
a pools winner

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 3 Old English pōl, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch poel and German Pfuhl. noun senses 4 to 7 late 17th cent. (originally denoting a game of cards having a pool): from French poule in the sense ‘stake, kitty’, associated with pool ‘small area of liquid’.
